{{otheruses}}
 
{{otheruses}}
−
'''Ethics''' (from the [[Ancient Greek]] {{polytonic|ἠθικός}} ''ēthikos'', the adjective of {{polytonic|ἤθος}} ''ēthos'' "custom, habit"), a major branch of [[philosophy]], is the study of [[Value theory|value]]s and [[Custom (law)|custom]]s of a person or group and covers the [[Philosophical analysis|analysis]] and employment of [[concept]]s such as [[right]], [[wrong]], [[good]], [[evil]], and [[moral responsibility|responsibility]]. It is divided into three primary areas: ''meta-ethics'' (the study of the concept of ethics), ''normative ethics'' (the study of how to determine ethical values), and ''applied ethics'' (the study of the use of ethical values).
+
'''Ethics''' (from the [[Ancient Greek]] {{polytonic|ἠθικός}} ''ēthikos'', the adjective of {{polytonic|ἤθος}} ''ēthos'' "custom, habit"), a major branch of [[philosophy]], is the study of [[Value theory|value]]s and [[Custom (law)|custom]]s of a person or group and covers the [[Philosophical analysis|analysis]] and employment of [[concept]]s such as [[right]] and [[wrong]], [[good and evil]], and [[moral responsibility|responsibility]]. It is divided into three primary areas: ''meta-ethics'' (the study of the concept of ethics), ''normative ethics'' (the study of how to determine ethical values), and ''applied ethics'' (the study of the use of ethical values).
